review.title: A Hackathon for Classical Tibetan
review.abstract: We describe the course of a hackathon dedicated to the development of linguistic tools for Tibetan Buddhist studies. Over a period of five days, a group of seventeen scholars, scientists, and students developed and compared algorithms for intertextual alignment and text classification, along with some basic language tools, including a stemmer and word segmenter.

sections.heading: 1.1 Dataset Preparation
sections.text: We used Tibetan Buddhist texts drawn from various sources and transcribed in accordance with the Wylie Convention [Wylie, 1959]. In this system, Tibetan is transliterated into Latin characters without diacritics; therefore, different Tibetan letters are represented by two or three Latin consonants; the texts had to be cleaned by removing Sigla and standardizing punctuation; the texts included the Tibetan Buddhist canon in digital form (we used a modified form of the Kangyur and Tengyur ACIP files provided by Paul Hacket of Columbia University) and several sets of autochthonous Tibetan Buddhist texts by various authors (compiled by Eric Werner of the University of Hamburg); in addition, it was necessary to prepare test suites with manually edited gold standard answers so that the power of algorithms to identify parallel passages and classify texts could be used (selected by Werner of Hamburg University).

sections.heading: 1.4 Text Classification
sections.text: The second important task addressed at the hackathon was the question of author profiling. While the question of the extent to which the problem of authorship can be addressed in the case of translated texts still needs to be investigated, some general research questions relating to authorship fall within the field of machine classification. These include the following: (a) distinction between translated texts and autochthonous texts; (b) determination of the period in which a text was written, ancient Tibetan (7-11. c.), classical Tibetan texts (11-14. c.), or classical Tibetan texts (15-20. c.); (c) determination of whether a translated canonical work belongs to the early period of translation (snga) or to the new period (phyi-14. c.); (d) in the case of autochthonous literature, the so-called open texts (6 Journal of Data Mining and Digital Humanities).
